en.value: Do you want something to eat?
We'll learn the names of some everyday food and drinks. All words are served with useful phrases. Enjoy! Here's a taster of the phrases we're going to look at:
Do you drink tea or coffee?
Select the words in the correct order.
Select the word which matches the image.
Match each group of foods with its category.
You need this to make a sandwich.
Could we have some water, please?
Do you take milk in your tea?
In Britain, tea is a popular hot drink. Most people add milk to their tea, and some add sugar as well.
He eats a lot of fruit.
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
Could I have some more vegetables?
Do you drink tea or coffee?
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
Select the most likely question based on the answer you hear.
What do you want to drink?
What do you want to eat?
What do you want to be?
Match each question with a response.
What do you want to drink?
What do you want to eat?
Fill in the gap using the image.
Fill in the gap using the audio.
He eats a lot of fr[k]u[/k][k]i[/k][k]t[/k].

There are two types of noun that we're going to learn: countable and uncountable. As the names suggest, countable nouns are things that we can count and uncountable nouns are things that we can't. Let's look at some examples.
Countable: I have two sandwiches for lunch.
Things that we can count, like "apples".
Things that we can't count, like "milk".
Match the words with their definitions.

Let's focus on countable nouns first. Typically, these nouns are the names of separate objects or people. They can be counted, so they have a plural form and we can use numbers or "some" with them. For their singular form, we can use "a" (or "an" before nouns beginning with a vowel).
Complete the sentence with the countable noun.
There is a [k]cake[/k] in the kitchen.
Complete the sentence with the correct countable noun.
Match the pairs of words / phrases.

Uncountable nouns are the names of materials, liquids, abstract ideas and other things which do not have clear boundaries. We see them as masses without clear boundaries, and so we can't count them and they have no plural form. We don't use numbers or "a / an" with them, but we can use "some".
Complete the sentence with the uncountable noun.

We say "there is / there are" when we want to express the existence or presense of something. We use: - "there is (some)" with uncountable nouns, - "there is a / an" with singular countable nouns, - "there are (some)" with plural countable nouns.
There is a dog in the garden.
There are four people in my family.
There is some [h]tea[/h] in the pot.
There are 12 people in my class.
There are five [h]rooms[/h] in my house.
There is sugar in the cupboard.
There is a [h]pizza[/h] on the table.
There is food in the kitchen.
There is some [k]fruit[/k] in the bowl.
Careful! "Fruit" is uncountable. Select the correct form for this sentence.
There are three [k]bananas[/k] in this cake.
Before we practise some more, let's recap.

- Countable nouns (e.g. apples, eggs, people) can be counted. They have a plural form. We can use "a / an" for singular nouns. We can use numbers or "some" for plural nouns. - Uncountable nouns (e.g. water, milk, bread) cannot be counted, so they mostly don't have a plural form. We can use them with or without "some". - We use "there is / there are" to talk about the existence or presence of something. - We use "there is" with uncountable nouns and singular countable nouns. - We use "there are" with plural countable nouns.
There is a cake in the kitchen.
Select the correct words to fill the gaps.
Fill in the gap using the hint.
Complete the sentence to express the existence or presence of something.
[k]There is|There's|There is some|There's some[/k] milk in the fridge.
[k]There is some|There's some[/k] pizza in the fridge.
What kind of noun is "water"? Complete the sentence with an appropriate word.
[k]There are[/k] seven people in my family
We already know a lot about countable and uncountable nouns. Let's have a look at more ways to talk about them!
Can I have a little sugar in my tea?
Do we have many apples in the house?
I want to buy a few oranges.
I want to make a [h]cake[/h] with some fruit in it. I think I have a few [h]apples[/h].
We don't need much [h]milk[/h] or many eggs. How much [h]butter[/h] do we have?
Did you notice how we use different words to talk about quantities in English? These are called quantifiers. Let's look at these again...
I think I have a few apples.
We don't need much milk or many eggs.
There are so [k]many[/k] shops on this street.
Is there much sugar in this cake?
You drink so [k]much[/k] coffee in the morning!
We use "a few" with countable nouns.
We only need a few eggs.
We need [k]a few[/k] eggs to make the cake.
We use "a little" with uncountable nouns.
Do you want a little milk in your coffee?
Can I have [k]a little[/k] honey in my tea, please?
This is too [k]much[/k] pasta. I can't eat it all!
How many raisins do I need?
How much butter do I need?

We use "much" and "many" to talk about large amounts, or to ask questions.

You will also see "so much" and "so many" often used for large amounts and "too much" and "too many" to talk about excessive amounts.
I can't eat this, there are too many chilli peppers in it.
The person speaking has a lot of oranges.
We use "a few" and "a little" to talk about small amounts. We do not normally use these to ask questions about how much there is of something.
How many potatoes do we need for dinner?
Can I have a little butter, please?
The person speaking wants a lot of sugar in her tea.
Could I have a little sugar in my tea, please?
She only wants a little sugar. This means she does not want a lot of sugar in her tea.
[k]How many[/k] sandwiches do we need for the party? I think there are only 2 guests, so we just need [k]a few[/k] sandwiches, right?
There are [h]a[/h] [h]few[/h] apples on the table.
How much milk do you want in your coffee?
Select the quantifiers we use with countable nouns.
I ate too much [k]food[/k] at lunch.
We only need a few [k]apples[/k] for the cake.

There are two ways of talking about large quantities that do not depend on countability: "lots of" and "a lot of". These two phrases can be used instead of "much" or "many" when speaking about large quantities.
I have many sisters. = I have lots of sisters. = I have a lot of sisters.
You drink so much coffee! = You drink lots of coffee! = You drink a lot of coffee!

Be careful with "a lot of" and "lots of" - these expressions are often seen as less formal. They are great to use when speaking, but in writing (especially in formal writing), they will not be appropriate. Use "many" or "much" for professional writing.
There are many teachers at this school.
There are a lot of teachers at this school.
There are many shops in London, especially on Oxford Street.
You might read this sentence in a newspaper.
Yes - "many" and "much" are both appropriate ways to talk about large quantities in writing.
There are lots of students at my university.
No, in formal writing, you'd be more likely to read "many" than "lots of".
There are only [k]a[/k] [k]few[/k] apples in the bowl.
There are [k]so many|many|lots of|a lot of[/k] people at this football match.
In the sentence "There is too much salt in this soup."...
The speaker is unhappy because there is so much salt.
The speaker is happy because there is so much salt.
The speaker is unhappy because there is very little salt.
Match the sentence to the level of formality.
There are many people in the world.
There are lots of people in the world.
There are [k]too many|so many|many|lots of|a lot of[/k] cars here!
